text: Hey Shailendra!:D The course has hit me and I'm up to my neck in assignments right now - one of which is a Python tool assignment in which we have to create a python tool. We're told to make a tool for Maya and we're taught Python for Maya. As I want to make a tool for Nuke the lecturer can't really help as much as he could with Maya so I've been trying to teach myself Python in Nuke :thumbsup: It's pretty overwhelming!
Speaking of which!!!! What do you think would be a useful Python tool in Nuke? I was thinking of creating an AOV/Pass splitter so I don't have to shuffle all of the passes out of a render manually.

We're also learning how to light and render in Houdini this year so it's a whole new software package to get used to but it's super exciting:) For our creative project (with the monkey), we're planning to do every part of the pipeline expect for modelling, rigging and animation in Houdini so we're trying our best to learn it as fast as possible.
We wrote the first draft of our script for the film recently, would you like to read it?:)
Thanks for checking up on me, Shailendra!:) I'll send through some of my assignment stuff once I have something to show. Super excited for your feedback as always.

Hey Callum!
nice to hear from you.
getting straight to your question

Python can be a great way to automate repeatable/tedious tasks. A Simple AOV splitter can be handy.

start with simple and add more features once you have something that works.
The trick to python is breaking a task into simple elements. getting each one to work.


you could create a 
def aovSplit():

make it do stuff, generate the appropriate node streams and so on
add conditionals(if else etc.) and exception handling

keep it simple. the code doesn’t have to super neat as long as it works.
#add comments so you can modify it later.

python basics should be roughly the same across platforms.
dictionaries, lists, tuples(words which essentially are a way to organize things and make stuff happen as a result)
e.g. you could query the number of channels in a selected read node, while also telling nuke to not do anything if it isn’t a read node
or pop a 
nuke. message(“please select a read node”)
Cool! Houdini/Mantra are popular tools at many studios especially for effects

great stuff!
taking a script and turning that into visuals is good learning experience.
quick tip for python if you type in the nuke script editor a few alphabets and press tab it shows you a list of functions
and there is always the internet
